author: zuzi

description.text:
The Low Fi Hi Tech headphones is a research Project to find out a way to create a fully functional pair of audio headphones without any manufactured part, this means all the parts of this headset are raw materials, such as wire, tape, solder, magnets and of course 3D printed parts.
The most challenging part was to make the right combination of 3D printed elements such as the speaker piece, the ear part had to be a good acoustic case and should to include a holder for the magnet, the speaker itself is a very thin printed part with a very thin rail to be able to insert the copper wire in it.
Once I got that part working, I decided to go further, drawing the plug to fit a standard Jack connector, this was a very tricky part because the model of this was a very thin part to print and creating the connections only with wire was a real challenge. Again it worked! And even if many people would hesitate to plug this weird looking but familiar plug, I can assure you it works with no risks on jamming inside your portable audio device. Anyway, the sound quality is very nice against all expectations but will necessitate a power amplifier to be louder when using only portable sources like pods or phones. The files are open to anyone who wantâ€™s to try to make a pair of these! Special thanks to Martin De Bie, Hannah Perner Wilson, Jean Baptiste Labrune whose work inspired me a lot in this particular Project. my website and email for additional info:
http://www.karich.cl
[email protected]

Material list: 3D printed parts:
  • 2 ear parts
  • 2 speaker parts
  • 1 headband
  • 2 extension bands
    • Electric:
  • Copper wire
  • Solder
  • Magnets 10x5mm round
  • Ribbon from fabrickit
  • steel or nickel metalic wire
    • Other
  • Insulation or krapton tape

title: Animated Heart Valentine.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A hand operated animated heart Valentine. Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F6l6FjOTfgU. Designed using Sketchup Make 2015, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42 "Standard" Settings (.2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill). Happy Valentines Day (also my birthday)!

Study "Assembly.skp".  
Print and assemble all pieces as shown in "Assembly.skp". I found "Heart.stl" prints best when the build plate is a little further from the print head than I normally set it.  After printing, carefully remove the hold down pads on "Base.stl" and "Frame.stl".  
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.  Pay close and careful attention to the small gaps between the pieces of "Heart.stl", making sure to remove any flashing and/or debris with a hobby knife or equivalent as "Heart.stl" must move smoothly without binding.  
Assemble as shown in "Assembly.skp".  
Lubricate all contacting moving surfaces with light machine oil.   
After final assembly and test, I apply a small dot of thick cyanoacrylate glue to heart lobes and point to hold "Heart.stl" securely if "Frame.stl".   
Comment if you have questions.  
Happy Valentines Day (also my birthday)!

author: FLATLINEcustoms

title: Juggler: The Wanhao/Makerbot Print Profile Editor - (Alternative to ProfTweak)

description.text:
While ProfTweak is way better to use than a text editor to edit MIRACLE.JSON files generated by Makeware I don't find it easy to use. Here is an alternative print profile editor for editing printer profiles used by Makerware. It is an not completed yet and does not include all the features. For instance those related to dynamic speed control or range checking in the fields. It does check for integer or decimal though and will beep if you put a period in an integer box or a letter in any number field. So please check back for the new version. I would welcome any feedback good or bad in relation to layout and usability, bugs, useless inclusions or useful omissions. I am unlikely to update this any further so feel free to download the source and edit it as you will. UPDATE - Added source code file UPDATE - 0.5.0.5 - Fixed some check box errors and added some more mouse over ToolTips. Added enable dynamic speed control.
Update - fixed default support extruder not being saved
Updated a couple of stupid compile errors where I left the gcode page hidden.
UPDATE - 0.5.0.3 - Includes Speed Controls
UPDATE - 0.5.0.1 - Support options and Start/End gcode editor
UPDATE - All tool tips and interface revamp. Better handling of exceptions and files.
UPDATE - Now tell you what profile you are working on and includes some of the mouse over tooltips in the fields.
UPDATE - Now has save as new profile feature

Unzip the file to wherever you want.
right click any .JSON file you can find and do "OPEN WITH"
setting always open with this, and point it at juggler.exe Check by double-clicking any miracle.json
or
Clicking edit profile in Makerware and it should open. Needs .NET 4.5
Windows 7 (Not tested with Win8. Program expects to find "My Things" folder in %userprofile%)
when you have finished changing your settings just click save&close If you want to create a new profile from the one you have opened enter the new name and click save. Clicking save with no new profile name will save the current changes to the opened profile. To reset changes close without saving changes use close from the file menu and reopen. The current open profile is indicated in the bottom left of the form.

remixed_from.title: Pi Supply Case for Raspberry Pi Model 2B and B+ with Opening Lid

title: Raspberry Pi model B+ or Pi2 model B case

description.text: A free and open source case for a Raspberry Pi model B+ or a Raspberry Pi 2 model B The original PDF file from Pi-Supply was scaled too small, it is now scaled at 100% and can be used to send to a laser cutter as it is. I have also added the attribution text to the base of the case as required by the CC-BY-SA license. The top of the case also features the Ipswich Makerspace logo This model is made out of 3mm hard board, I think it is actually very slightly thicker than 3mm so some of the tabs were a bit tight. If made from 3mm acrylic is should all go together fine. Revision 3 - power socket hole has been enlarged.

I got this case laser cut from 3mm thick hard board.
  • Put the two long sides onto the base
  • Place the Pi inside the case
  • Open the sides and slot in the lid
  • Fit the end with the USB and ethernet holes
  • Fit the other end
  • Shut the lid
    • Done, easy.

comments.text: I finally managed to get them to stay stuck to the bed. I use blue painter tape. Then print with a brim of about 7 mm. Just after the brim has printed and the feet first layer i will pause the print, lift the extruder a bit and run a small drop of ca glue along the outside edge of the brim. Remove them with tape from the glass and tape new. That is better than having them come lose. Works for me.

Mini box that allows you to fix the converter module to the3Drag printer frame.
3Drag site: http://www.open-electronics.org/3drag-3d-printer/

NOTE!  This isn't a weapon, or intended to be used as any kind of projectile.   It's a model only, it'll probably break your firearm if you try to load it, it'll probably break your printer if you print it, and knowing my abhorrent OpenSCAD skills, it'll probably blow up your computer if you download it.   Don't be stupid.
OpenSCAD script for generating bullet models.   Amateurish code, but it seems like it'll work.  Handy for making snap caps, or for designing other parts.   And for people who will say 'that's a cartridge, not a bullet', I know.

Script includes 9mm Parabellum as well as .45 ACP, but can easily be changed to include other models.   
All models are flat-nosed, since I didn't know how to make them proper shapes.   
I'm learning how to stretch spheres in OpenSCAD, but I'm not quite there yet.  I'll post an update if I get something with a better profile.

title: Safety Corner for IKEA LACK tables

description.text: This rounded corner can be fixed to most of the tables from the collection IKEA LACK. It uses the screwable table leg to stay secure. It can be easily mounted and unmouted without ruining your furnitures.

I recommend 20% infill. You do not want more because it would make a harder corner, you do not want less because you don't want it to be too fragile.  
At least one support is required to hold the extremity of the overhang. I used 4 in simplify 3d. It attached a picture of where I decided to add support.  
Print it, slightly unscrew one leg, slide it in, screw the leg back, done, do all the corners and let the kid play ;-)

remixed_from.title: Lulzbot TAZ stiffened X motor and bearing mounts

title: 400mm TAZ 1-3 Upgraded to 16"/400mm cubed build area, LaZ16

description.text:
TAZ and Lulzbot fans worldwide,
This is a work in progress only because of the amount of data needed to get all the info listed here on Thingiverse. The LaZ16 printers have been built, are proven and the three completed printers have completed hundreds if not over a thousand combined hours of printing small and large pieces. Is your TAZ too small for the things you really want to print? Does your girlfriend tell you that she wants a full sized FrostMourne sword for her collection? Get the biggest printer on the block and print an Iron Man suit or Thunderlord rifle today! I have been sitting on these models for about a year and am currently finishing up my 3rd build of the LaZ16. This upgrade replaces most of the printed parts on a TAZ1-3 with stronger and revised pieces incorporating many individual upgrades listed here on Thingiverse and many more created by me, to give a TAZ a greatly increased build area of 400mm cubed. I will soon be giving credits and adding and filling out the BOM listings with current pricing and locations to acquire the various hardware to perform this upgrade. These modifications flips the X axis and extends the X and Y axis to 600mm replacing the smooth rods with 12mm 600mm long rods.
At this point you can save all the Z axis hardware and not replace the rods or frame extrusions.
With just replacing the four vertical aluminum frame extrusions you can extend the Z-axis by 50mm for more printable height. On complete builds we include 650mm tall extrusions and 600mm long smooth rods and threaded rods increasing the Z-axis build height to almost 400mm tall. Yes! I have the beautiful 400mmX400mm Kapton heaters for this bad boy in 12V and 24V. Contact me here if you need one quick and look for them on Ebay soon. I also have these huge complete printers for sale with a four week lead time. More to come as I get a chance and think of the needs.

Info on building and sourcing the hardware as I get time and energy to get it up here. --------2-18-15 -------------------------more to come The upgrade to a 16"/400mm bed requires replacing many of the printed parts of a TAZ. It also requires extensive wiring, extending wire looms and adding cooling to the y-axis stepper motor. We add heat sinks and fans to the X and Y axis stepper motors. The smooth rods on the X and Y Axis are upgraded to 12mm diameter with hardened steel for LMU12 roller bearings. McMaster does not sell 10mm rods in 600mm or 1200mm lengths so it was easier and a better build to upgrade to 12mm. This does require the cutting in half of 12mmX1200mm hardend steel rods. I use a 4" grinder with cutting wheel. These listed parts are for an increase in bed area but no increase in height of printer. The stock Z-axis 10mm smooth rods have 50mm of free length that can be used to raise the printable height by purchasing four 550mm 20x20mm extrusions from MisumiUSA for an easy and relatively cheap increase in height. Otherwise, it is a bigger project to go any taller. We build complete LaZ16s using 650mm tall extrusions for the vertical printers frame, making a nice big build volume, but requires new z-axis smooth rods and threaded rods. Printed Parts:
1x Double Bearing Holder 12mm bearings-------------TAZ16DoubleBearingHolder12mm30-4mmfooted.stl
5x Single Bearing Holder 12mm bearings--------------TAZ16YAxis12mmSinglebearingholder.stl
2x Z-axis Frame Mount lower 10mm rods--------------TAZ16ZMotorMount6mmOffset10mmSmoothrodStiffenedFooted.stl
2x Z-axis Frame Mount Upper 10mm rods-------------TAZX16ZRodTopMountrepairedFooted.stl
1x Y-axis Motor Mount Stiffened 12mm--------------TAZ16Ymotormountfooted12mmrods.stl
1x Y-axis Idler bearing Mount Stiffened 12mm------------TAZ16YidlerExtraStrength12mmrods.stl
1x X-axis Motor Mount 12mm------------TAZ16stiffenedXAxisMotorMountfooted12mmrods.stl
1x X-axis Idler bearing Mount 12mm--------------TAZ16XAxisIdlerFootedStiffer12mm.stl
1x X-axis End Stop Mount------------TAZ16XEndStopMountFooted.stl
1x Y-axis Bed Belt Mount cleaned--------------TAZ16YBeltMountCleanedRibsFooted.stl
4x Bed Corner Brackets optional-------------TAZM4cornerBracket.stl
4x Adjusting nuts for bed corners------------TAZm4CornerNutV2x1.stl
several Tnut loom brackets for securing wiring-----------TNutLoomBracketFooted.stl Purchased Hardware:
Purchased Parts:
1x 20 tooth pulley 5mm bore for Y-axis stepper motor
http://www.robotdigg.com/product/9/GT2-Pulley-20-Teeth-5mm-Bore
Cheapest place I have found for many items but the shipping starts at $30 for FedEx so it is best to get as many items as possible. My shipment showed up in like two days from China 2x Stepper Motor heat sinks
http://www.robotdigg.com/product/37/Nema17-size-stepextruder-heatsink 2x: 12mm x 1200mm Hardened Steel Smooth Rod $37.51 /each 1200mmRod
http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/120/1091/=qx6xe4 2x Zinc yellow-chromate Plated alloy steel threaded rods M6 1mm pitch $6.36 /1meter rod
http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/120/3174/=qx6xsr 7x LM12UU 12mm Linear Ball Bearing Bushing the following includes 8 $12.59 free shipping
http://www.ebay.com/itm/8pcs-LM12UU-12mm-Linear-Ball-Bearing-Bush-Bushing-New-/390220963542?pt=LH_DefaultDomain_0&hash=item5adafb5ed6 1 bag of 100 of M3x0.5 Metric Brass Heat-Set insert for plastic $12.12
http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/120/3293/=qx70tt 1x 5feet Extreme-Temperature Tubing Made with Teflon PTFE incase stock length isnt enough $8.45/5feet
http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/120/144/=qx71ze 3x feet GT2 2mm Timing Belt by the foot for longer X axis $2.50/foot $7.50
http://openbuildspartstore.com/gt2-2mm-timing-belt/ 1x 25pack Tee Nuts (might or might not need) $4.50 /pack
http://openbuildspartstore.com/tee-nuts-25-pack/ 1x 16" Glass plate
http://www.behrenbergglass.com/flat-glass/flat-clear-ds-glass/16-square-ds-flat-glass/ $10.12 each +$15.79 shipping for two
I bought two and paid $15.79 to ship both
These have been very resilient and I have not needed to spend the quoted $274.00 for a 16" square Borosilicate glass plate Various sized wire, heat shrink, corrigated black wire loom(auto parts, 1/4 and 3/8 inch), to extend x-axis motor and z-axis limit switch wiring. May have to lengthen y-axis wiring for motor and switch.
Wire Ties

6061-T6 ALUMINUM SHEET / PLATE .125" (1/8") ALUMINUM SHEET 6061-T6 17"x17" $36.41+$18.88+$4.56=$59.85
https://www.onlinemetals.com/merchant.cfm?pid=1246&step=4&id=76&top_cat=60 cut to 17"x17" Heat Spreader Aluminum plate. 400mm x 400mm Kapton heater glues to the bottom of this plate 7075-T6 BARE ALUMINUM SHEET/PLATE 0.050" 16"x16" $27.65+$18.34ship+$3.79tax=$49.78
https://www.onlinemetals.com/merchant.cfm?pid=12658&step=4&showunits=inches&id=916&top_cat=0 cut 16"x16" or Aluminum 6061-T6 Bare Sheet PVC 1 side 0.05" Cut to: 16" x 16" $20.48+$16.10ship+$2.88tax=$39.46
https://www.onlinemetals.com/merchant.cfm?pid=1241&step=4&id=76&top_cat=60 cut 16"x16" 400mmX400mm Kapton Heater for the large bed in 12v or 24V.
We recommend the 24V heater as both heaters are limited to 15amps giving the 24V heater double the wattage and faster heating. We also recommend adding a second power supply for the heated bed circuit on the TAZ Rambo, also available with the heaters on Ebay soon.

title: printable T profile belt with soft PLA

description.text:
Soft pla is a very good material to print. After the first experiments with the feed and flow rate on my mendel reprap, I found a working profile. Slow but strong.
Just for fun I tried to make a copy of a part of the belt around my x-axis. Because the soft pla has the same color - light grey - I had this idea. OpenSCAD again proofed to be very good for things like that. I made a singe pattern of one tooth and the following gap and copied it 20 times. The comparison to the original belt was stunning. The next step was printing an endless belt. The design with openSCAD was a bit tricky, but I never stop learing commands.
For this I had to tweak the skeinforge profile a little, but the result was worth tuning: The belt is fitting. I tested it with some mendel parts screwed together and fixed on my desk. The endless belt is around 380 mm - quite ok and not the maximum at all.
It is very though, but not tought enough - you can break it with brute force. But the elasticity is ok. It stretches about 2 mm (~0.5%) until it breaks.
Not comparable to the belts used in the reprap machines but more resistant than ever expected. More about this and where to get this soft PLA on: www.ifeelbeta.de Greetings
BonsaiBrain
Print it with soft PLA, turn around, fix to some gears and have fun!

title: Connection box with switch for power supply

description.text:
Esta caja se ha diseñado para albergar el conector hembra de una fuente de alimentacíon ATX. Tambien se ha aprovechado el interruptor que corta el encendido. De esta forma damos uso a una fuente de alimentación que iba a ir a la basura. Como veis tambien hemos aprovechado el ventilador de 12cm, activandose cuando encendemos el sistema. El enchufe es para conectar una raspberry pi en mi caso, pero se puede conectar un flexo.   
This box is designed to accommodate the female of a ATX power supply connector. We also took advantage switch which cuts the ignition. Thus we use a power supply that would go away. As you can see we have also used the 12cm fan, activating when we turn on the system. The plug is to connect a raspberry pi in my case, but you can connect a hose.

Hay que tener en cuenta que la tapa está mirando hacia abajo, con lo que tenemos que darle la vuelta para que quede mirando al reves. Giro de 180 grados, para que quede mirando hacia arriba y que no haya problemas de impresión.  
Keep in mind that the cap is facing down, so we have to turn it over so that it faces backwards. 180 degrees, so it is looking up and you have no problems printing.

But if you do, don't worry you can just print out another clip and glue it back on.

The idea of using 3D printing to build entire houses has been around for a while now. But in construction, smaller applications are often much more important or can be applied more rapidly. The classic power socket has remained unchanged for years. Despite this, there are many new applications imaginable for power sockets that more effectively reflect modern society and the way we use electricity. 3D printing opens up opportunities for these new applications: Unconventional shapes
It is possible to take existing wall sockets and develop new and interesting designs. One example is a printed power socket that goes around the corner. Power socket with USB port
Power sockets combined with a five-volt output (usb input) that can be used to charge mobile phones, etc. The wall structure behind it contains an extra wall socket with a transformer to convert 220-volt alternating current to 5-volt direct current. Designed by Zjenja Doubrovski, PhD student Design for Additive Design.
Featured at the Bouwbeurs 2015, Utrecht the Netherlands.
printed upside down with a brim and without supports. prints fast but acceptable at 0.2mm layer height and 2mm shell thickness (20% infill).

title: MHQ2 Landing gear XT60 Plug LED Strip

description.text: February 16, 2015 After printing and fitting the V2 on my MHQ2 I realized that while the landing gear works fine with the angled part facing out it hits one of the frame supports if you turn it around. Shaved off 1.8mm from the base to make it fit either way. Update Feb 13, 2015 - After printing my first set I realized that I put the bolt holes in the wrong place. Corrected and uploaded a new STL. Also added V2 with a 10mm wider base as well as correcting a few drawing errors. I needed some landing gear that would accomodate an XT60 Plug and still have a flat surface to mount an LED strip to for some running lights for racing. Didn't find what I needed so I tried my hand at building one myself. Not the fanciest thing out there but it should do the job. Thought i'd share.

description.text: A lightweight, adjustable clamp for gluing small parts.

Adjustable spring clamp.
Uses a clothespin spring like these others do:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:307551
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:677020 This one can span anything up to about 6 inches (150mm). Jaw depth is near 2.25 inches. The arms get jammed when clamped, and won't slip. There's a little bit of flex, but not much.
It turned out great on the first attempt. The "arm" sections were a smooth, sliding fit, and I didn't want to mess around making things thicker for more stiffness. It's really not needed for holding small pieces together as glue dries.
I'd guess the clamp applies about one pound (1/2 kilo) of pressure. A complete set of 4 pieces (2+2) required 49 minutes, 25 grams ABS using 0.3mm layers at normal speed. I'd go with 0.3mm layers or finer for smooth surfaces. A touch of sandpaper may be beneficial to the fit. Metric versions included.

remixed_from.title: Coil Jig for different rod sizes V2

title: Coil Jig for different rod sizes V3

description.text:
This is a coil Jig design enhancement. You can create coils of Kanthal or Nickle wire easily with this jig. Insert a M3 machine screw in one of the holes for the wire guage size on one cylinder.
Insert the center smooth rod, and fix it with grub screw on the other cylinder.
Insert wire thru the hole opening next to the rod. Hold the end of wire (that comes out of the cylinder) with your thumb, and rotate it once around the center smooth rod to start the coil.
Insert the protruding center smooth rod thru the center axial hole in the second cylinder, and start rotating it to make a coil.
The machine screw will keep the wire in place while rotating so that you will make a good coil easily. The faces A, B, C, D are marked on the cylinder in case you are coiling a stiff wire. If you start at A reference mark, it will be your reference to end your coil at A or C reference marks. Twist it to B or D in case of a stiff wire to account for spring back. The screw holes for the machine screw are not threaded, so they may require some force to get the screws in the first time. They are configured so that the machine screw will press the coil to the center rod for the selected guage wire hole. Based on my last print, I made some minor improvements for faster printing. This Jig can be setup to create a uniform spaced spiral coil. Check the pics attached. All you need is an angle head screw in place of a machine screw. NOTE: I am yet to print and test this design out. You are welcome to try and let me know if any fixes are required.

comments.text: Going to try and print this for wifey. She likes making coils but had to stop because of arthritis in her hands and this would be a great option that might help her.

comments.author: Jimmy06

description.text: Until conditioner bottles start getting smaller instead of bigger, picking them up in the shower may remain difficult.  This is especially true when they are surrounded by other bottles; leaving only the cap available for grabbing.  To offer more conditioner bottle control, I unveil the Bottle Throttle.

I thought of this thing immediately subsequent to dropping a large shampoo bottle on my toes while in the shower. The ensuing spike of pain allowed for clarity of thought and the Bottle Throttle was born. This is the companion to the Bottle Throttle - Shampoo. To offer some variety and to ensure the two handle designs did not interfere with each other when side by side, they are somewhat different. The current SketchUp model is designed for a 28mm diameter male threaded bottle opening and a 31mm diameter female threaded bottle cap.

  • Resize in SketchUp as needed.

  • Print. I did not find that support materials were necessary given the arch design. Leave the thing a bit rough to allow for additional grip. If your prints are very smooth on all sides, I recommend roughing up the surface a bit with some sandpaper.

  • Insert between bottle opening and cap, leaving grips facing up.

  • Enjoy better conditioner bottle control.
    • Happy Printing. ~GearsOfWow

title: The All You Can Feed Buffet v1.3 :-)

description.text:
!!! Currently under construction (...PAUSED for an unspecified period...). Content might be faulty and incomplete. This package will be gradually expanded to include additional content. If interested, please check regularly back here.!!! • This is "CPv7-BEMF" - UNIVERSAL (Bowden Extruder-Material-Feeder). To have the BEST, maybe NO. But to have the MOST UNIVERSAL, maybe YES :-) :-) :-)
• This ELEVEN -parts object is one component of my One Man - *Co.Me.Do.ONE - project. CP-v7 (Co.Me.Do. - Part No: 7). To use this printable object, additional components are required. • Description #1
• The All You Can Feed Buffet...
• MENU 1: The complete CPv7 Download Package for 3mm and 2.85mm Filament (Already available).
• MENU 1.1: !!! Great stability improvements to the feeder base (Today: 2014-12-16) !!!
• The basic design has been completely revised again ... BEMF - Reloaded :-)
• Significantly lower breakage / will bend Risk of all static elements, with the use of possibly substandard filaments for the construction of the feeder.
• The Bowden guide on the base now allow easier insertion and removal of the standard Bowden tubing OD: 6 / ID: 4mm.
• The two stabilizing bridges were revised slightly. • MENU 1.3: !!! Stability improvements to the feeder base (Today: 2015-12-22) !!! • MENU 1.5: Carriages for alternative couplings eg. UM - Tube collet (Will be soon available).
• MENU 2: The complete CPv7 Download package for 3mm, 2.85mm and 1.75mm Filament (Will soon be available).
• MENU 3: SketchUp source files (Will soon be available). • Description #2:
• The CPv7-BEMF-v1 basic design has completed over 750 hours of operation successful.
• Universal "Bowden-Extruder - Material-Feeder", suitable for filaments with a diameter of 3mm, 2.85mm, and later 1.75mm.
• Based on the conventional unicycle-principle: Suitable for a variety of knurled and hobbed drive wheels.
• Finely adjustable uniform pressure, and the lowest possible friction: A large counterpressure roller (608ZZ-Bearing), and two limiting rollers (624ZZ-Bearing), can reliably carry material through the couplings in the Bowden.
• One hundred percent compatible with the Ultimaker 2 machine, Software and firmware adjustments are NOT required. But fully universally applicable.
• Modular feeder structure: Adjustable guide slides available for different hard and thick filaments: Even flexible filaments, for example Ninja Flex (Layer: 0.1mm / speed. 20-25mm/s.) can be printed with CPv7. But tests with very soft filaments are currently not yet completed.
• Depending on the selected guide slides, an almost trouble-free material change is possible: it needs a little force for inserting new material, it must be straightened slightly only in the initial region. The adjustment of the spring tensioning lever can be moved temporarily close to zero, this allows an added locking lever.
• A very reliable and almost wear-free operation is possible depending on the correct implementation. A simple work for a 3D printer, and a not too complicated work for the user. All optional components are relatively cheap to buy. You need for a successful reproduction a generally functioning 3D printer. Unfortunately, a whole long printing time is expected. Ask at best an experienced friend or colleague to accompanying Support.
• Very stable Bowden guide (Bowden Fix) at the top outlet: The lower material supply can be easily implemented by means of a short length Bowden. An almost free of play support for the Bowden tube in direct interaction with the presented powerful pneumatic couplings, shorter retractions are possible, and a sudden grip loss is almost unthinkable. But there will be later carriages for alternative couplings.
• Integrated cable Management.
• There are different covers to choose from: The installation of a neutral variant is easy to implement.
• Versions for left and right rear panel mounting available. Note for Ultimaker 2 users: Please use the right version. The left version is currently not optimized for extruder 2 operation, and does not fit on the rear Panel. • Information regarding enhancements and bug fixes you will find in the "Comment" section. Photos with the already assembled object does not show the latest design.
• Again and again: My work for you lives solely by your feedback. If something is wrong or useless in my designs, I need more information from you so that I can ever change anything. Suggestions to improve or simplify my designs and descriptions are highly desirable. So if you use my designs and parts thereof, please take a few moments to convey a little feedback.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

33%

!!! CAUTION !!!  
•SORRY, BUT: This is not for people who dip their biscuits in the coffee ... not for the impatient wimps...Please go ahead and look for simple Solutions :-)  
•For proper material feed please make sure that you always use a clean print head. This strong material feeder does not remove any existing problems caused by the printhead.  
•ALL 3D objects created with SketchUpMake. / All hard Materials usable...This parts printed with: InnoFill and Ultimaker PLA / Layer: 0.1mm / Infill: =>35 Percent / Temp: 215 Degree / Speed: 35>>>70mm/s.  
•PLEASE print all items with identical settings.  
•WARNING: Avoid PLA printing with insufficient infill (less than 33%) in combination with temperatures below 205 degrees. Objects with fine static structures can be very unstable due to poor Layer-Adhesion. Incorrect retraction settings, such as for example too long or too fast retractions can cause big problems in an object with small static elements.  
•PLEASE use a special printing surface, so your objects get almost smooth and mate base areas, also lower platform temperatures are possible.  
•PLEASE use the glas printing surface, so your objects get almost glossy base areas.  
•DIRECT PRINTING ON GLASS: High risk of material Warping and complete detachment from the glass surface, especially for very large objects and insufficient build platform temperatures less than 60 degrees. An excessive build platform temperature higher than 70 degrees, can cause object deformations and dimensional inaccuracies mainly in areas near the glass surface.  
•BEFORE THE RELEASE, there was an almost 500 hours continuous test phase, besides, many components have been optimized and revised several times. Provided that your machine can produce nearly flawless reproductions, then you get a very reliable and universally applicable instrument.  
•ULTIMAKER 2 OWNER MUST NOT MAKE CHANGES directly on the machine / software / Firmware: CPv7 was created for the UM2. But, ONE additional 4mm diameter hole in the UM2 backplane brings more mechanical stability for the spring tension lever.  
•WARNING: The CPv7 couplings are choosen for 6mm Bowden. The original UM and UM2-PTFE-Bowden has a diameter of OD: 6.35mm / ID: 3.17mm. Reduce the initial diameter of an original UM-Bowden (recommended) over a total length of at least 15mm, or use a OD: 6.00 / ID: 4.00mm-Bowden (Not recommended).  
•An illustrated guide is available in a separate "Hints" download package.  
•If anything does not fit immediately properly then please no assembly by brute force. Sometimes suffice minor corrections with a nail file or more specific tools. Also a re-print of perhaps five to ten degrees lower or higher temperature can help.

title: type a mechines series 1 2014 filament holder

description.text:
ok so type a machines ships there 2014 series 1 with a filament holder. they also ship with a tiny bit of filament. and if your like me and want to print large size objects then your going to want filament. lucky for me my home depot has the makerbot and filament for it. bad part is the spool that is used to hold the filament is very large. and the spool holder cannot hold that size spool  
well good news i made a spool holder that can be used to hold makerbots larger spools very well. my design requires you to drill the holes a bit larger for the screws to hold the printed part . but the final product works great.   
using the spool holder in combination with the lower guide designed by jmungapen001 you get great prints and no dragging sounds from the filament rubbing against the plate

using cura settings are
quality

title: The qInch Project : Mini Claw Grip

description.text:
Main Project Page - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668017 Today I thought about remixing the Adjustable Claw Grip. My thoughts are that people may want something smaller, less parts to print and only really care about holding a phone or something else that isn't to big. Plus, all the extra bolts/nuts that have been removed will make the overall piece much lighter in weight. I have yet to print this part, but I took the source of the original and merged the 4 parts into 2. So I believe this will print just fine. I'll def print at some point and post the images. Hardware Needed
  • Three Inch 1/4-20 bolt and lock not to piece together the top and bottom halves.
  • 1/4-20 16mm(or larger) cross dowel nut
  • Whatever size bolt that works best with how far you want the clamp part to open that will be attached to the dowel nut.
    • Freecad Source Included

After testing the first scraper I decided to make this slightly longer one.
I finally got this printed and it came out to be 230 mm long. It turns out that because it's very long it gets very thin towards the tip so it becomes a flexible scraper which still works. It bends if you bend it which should work fine for removing extra filament or other small things off the bed that can't be reached.

I suggest printing it on its side or you will get steps instead of a smooth angle. Make sure to add supports to the corners or use a brim to make sure it won't lift. I have started using a few supports to test out so I don't have to trim the full part all the way around.  
I printed this without any support so it works too. I did find out that it's better to print one at a time. I put both long scrapers and one always seems to move and not work.

title: Tennis Ball Holder - for slitting balls

description.text:
After reading about someone's difficulty slitting tennis balls for use on a walker, it occurred to me that a holder could greatly simplify the process, and perhaps help avoid injury.  This is the first shot at a 3D printable holder.  It's meant to be used with rubber bands to help keep things together while the ball is slit with a box cutter or razor knife.  While investigating commercial alternatives (>$100, by the way), I found that teachers also use slit tennis balls on the feet of student desks to cut down on classroom noise.  Perhaps you have another use.  
This is not a stellar OpenSCAD file, but if you can decipher it the variables below should help you modify things to your heart's content.

Caveat - I have not printed this yet.  I have an idea for a simpler version, depending on whether the person I was thinking of has a vice.  
This consists of two separate pieces, the upper and the lower.  
The lower holder can be printed with a low infill.  The upper holder should be printed with enough perimeters to make it robust in the knife slot area.

remixed_from.title: The qInch Project : Spring Phone Grip

title: The qInch Project : Spring Phone Grip v2

description.text:
Main Project Page : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:668017 So here's version 2 of the phone grip. More streamlined, less parts and using only 2 compression springs that will live inside the extended part. Just pop the springs in and use 2 bolts to keep them inside. The homedepot link is one spring that I tested. It fits but it has alot of tension. The amazon set has a compression spring which has less tension but works much better. So the strength will vary based on how strong the spring is and how long the bolts you use. Side note, When i put this together I noticed if I put a bolt through the center that is ment to attach to a tripod or other qInch parts, I can basically use the bolt as a kickstand, so this grip can double as a phone stand. So that's kinda neat way to use this new part. Hardware Used
  • Any length 1/4-20 bolts you need to match the height of the device you want to clamp onto. (I use 3 inch bolts for phones)
  • Four Nuts.
  • Two 3/8in x 1 1/8in x .041 in Compression Spring. You may try other springs that you can stuff inside the space.
    • http://www.homedepot.com/p/Unbranded-Zinc-Plated-Compression-Springs-6-Pack-16087/202045468 http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000K7M36W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 Freecad Source Included.

Incorrect retraction settings, such as for example too long or too fast retractions can cause big problems in an object with small static elements. •PLEASE use a special printing surface, so your objects get almost smooth and mate base areas, also lower platform temperatures are possible. •PLEASE use the glas printing surface, so your objects get almost glossy base areas. •DIRECT PRINTING ON GLASS: High risk of material Warping and complete detachment from the glass surface, especially for very large objects and insufficient build platform temperatures less than 60 degrees. • Project finished, there are no planned updates. • Customise your Ultimaker 2...away from the omnipresent monotony. If you like pea soup every day?...Then rather change "nothing" :-) !!! ATTENTION !!! HIGH LEVEL OF DIFFICULTY !!!
To obtain good to very good results and avoid frustration, please read all warnings and instructions available here carefully.
• This 2 Parts are components of my One Man - *Co.Me.Do.ONE - project. CP-v8 (Co.Me.Do. - Part No: 8). To use this printable objects, no additional components are required. • Description:
• Here you have your own personal options:
• Create cool looking and perfectly fitting engine covers for your very own "Ultimaker 2".
• Accept either the basic design and use your preferred material / color. And or do something even better from it. If you're already familiar with "SketchUp", then you can change and further customize these covers.
• Have the courage and show your very own engine covers :-)
• Are you looking for an easy way to cool the engines of your lovely machine ? The covers already include a holder for standard 40 mm fans, which can be used if necessary.
• And for now (2015-02-11) a basic set for passive cooling is included.
• All prints done?...So go ahead...Each original engine cover has only a single easy-to-find screw ! • Information regarding enhancements and bug fixes you will find in the "Comment" section. Photos with the already assembled object does not show the latest design.
• Again and again: My work for you lives solely by your feedback. If something is wrong or useless in my designs, I need more information from you so that I can ever change anything. Suggestions to improve or simplify my designs and descriptions are highly desirable. So if you use my designs and parts thereof, please take a few moments to convey a little feedback.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

33%

!!! CAUTION !!!
  • ALL 3D objects created with SketchUpMake. / All Materials usable...This parts printed with: InnoFill and Ultimaker PLA / Layer: 0.1mm / Infill: =>35 Percent / Temp: 215 Degree / Speed: 35>>>70mm/s.
  • Disadvantages there are basically no. "PLA" is quite sufficient, because it must be used no special heat-resistant material. Unless you use your Ultimaker 2 in tropical regions, then you better take "ABS".
  • CHALLENGE: Try it on a single object to get two good-looking exterior surfaces.
  • NOTES: Position the objects diagonally on the construction area. Do not use a skirt or brim, because it requires too much additional space.
  • WARNING: An improperly mounted UM2 printhead fans frame may collide with the retaining clips of the build platform. Check precisely the correct position of the fan frame, before the start of printing very large objects.
  • PLEASE print all items with identical settings.
  • WARNING: Avoid PLA printing with insufficient infill (less than 33%) in combination with temperatures below 205 degrees. Objects with fine static structures can be very unstable due to poor Layer-Adhesion. Incorrect retraction settings, such as for example too long or too fast retractions can cause big problems in an object with small static elements.
  • PLEASE use a special printing surface, so your objects get almost smooth and mate base areas, also lower platform temperatures are possible.
  • PLEASE use the glas printing surface, so your objects get almost glossy base areas.
  • DIRECT PRINTING ON GLASS: High risk of material Warping and complete detachment from the glass surface, especially for very large objects and insufficient build platform temperatures less than 60 degrees. An excessive build platform temperature higher than 70 degrees, can cause object deformations and dimensional inaccuracies mainly in areas near the glass surface.
  • If anything does not fit immediately properly then please no assembly by brute force. Sometimes suffice minor corrections with a nail file or more specific tools. Also a re-print of perhaps five to ten degrees lower or higher temperature can help.

title: Prototypes - test objects - And much more

description.text: • Various small tests, suitable mainly around the Ultimaker 2, but also for other 3D printer. NozzleSize: ~0.42mm / Walls: 0.43mm. The use is entirely at your own risk and responsibility.

• Whatever you want to test... • Note: Some items available here are not printable and have no description. So do not be surprised, because I use this area also for other purposes. • Some objects here are almost finished prototypes, and possibly later, they are available as tested thingis. If you have some time to spare, then you might make a few printing tests with various filaments, and give me some feedback between. If you particularly like some of it, and you would like to participate on the improvement, then please use the contact options on the Website. • And in some object regions are often shown in red: "Support-materials" , "Support-structures" , which has to be completely removed after printing. Quick explanations:
• Test-Accuracy(M3M4) - This is for finding out what settings are required, so that the screw types will sit well later. • Test-AxisMoving - Disable all skirt. - This is a simple motion test for all axis, which reaches a very wide range of the UM2 platform. - Be careful, fan trays can collide with the bed retaining clips that you must correct before! - Pay attention to the amount of noise, sounds like everything is normal for you ready? - Let this test run very slow if you want to lubricate the axis cozy. At the end, the quality of the resulting walls Explore exactly. Is everything okay, do you like it so? • Test-BedAlignment - Disable all skirt. - Here you have the possibility to check whether the alignment of the print bed is sufficiently good. - This is an important exercise before much expensive material is wasted. • Test-Surface - A little test to the first examination of the surface quality, using a simple object. - Print the object without infill to determine the required top and bottom-thickness - Or determine the quantity of infill for a good finish. • Test-Wall e 043 - Another small test, which is mainly used to determine the Print Quality. - Print multiple identical objects with different materials, for determining of the material quality. - Print multiple identical objects, with varying settings to determine the best settings for a very specific material.

description.text:
Create a desktop fan using a matrix of standard 80mm computer fans. It can be just about any size matrix you want. All the parts are completely modular. You can make a 3x3, 2x2, 2x1, or whatever. When assembled, the structure is solid and amazingly very low power. Mine registered just above 1 amp at 12 volts. Handy if you are out camping or have a power failure and just happen to have a nice high capacity battery laying around. The grills are intentionally larger than the fan to create a gap so the wiring has room. There is a compartment in the bases so you can connect up the ends and tuck them out of the way. You can either buy quality, cheap, or flashy fans. A cheap set of fans and screws should only cost about $25 for a 3x3 Fan Matrix. Enjoy!
Mark :-) UPDATES: 02/16/2015
Fixed "bracket 1-hole" and added new "side plates" for a smoother and more refined look. 02/18/2015
Added an additional plate for mounting a DC-022 power jack. 02/19/2015
Oops. Fixed power jack plate.

Standard 80x80x25mm Case Fans (buy in multi-packs to save money). http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00NTUJG62
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KB8CB9O
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004KJ6AHY You will need a LOT of fan screws. Even if your fan comes with screws. You need 8 screws per fan. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0002AFTD6 Add a DC-022 power jack and a standard 12V 2.0A DC Adapter to power it. You can get a smaller amp rating if you are using less fans. Just add up the amps from the fan specs and leave a little extra room. Just make sure it's a UL listed power supply. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IXGLY9E
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00KZ2ZQE8
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MNU69L4 How about wireless RF remote speed control? I haven't tested this just yet, but it's on order. http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MHKCTLE

remixed_from.author: AL2327
remixed_from.title: XYZ Filament Spool Re- Winder for Drill

description.text: This heavy duty device lets you chuck up the internal spool from a XYZPrinting Da Vinci filament cartridge in a drill, so that you can rewind new filament onto it.  No 3D printed screw threads to worry about, or tiny engagement teeth to break off!

• Dimensions: 4.285"W x 4.285"D x 2.625"H (assembled)
  • Volume: 7.94 cubic inches (both pieces combined)
  • Weight: ~0.29 pounds (both pieces combined)

• Side A - with teeth: PTW-00-1-PT-0207 (Filament Spool Rewinder, Side A).STL
  • Side B - no teeth: PTW-00-1-PT-0208 (Filament Spool Rewinder, Side B).STL

• QTY 1: 1/4" bolt, 4 1/2" long
  • QTY 1: 1/4" wingnut
  • QTY 2: 1/4" ID, large OD fender washer

• .STL names do not match .SLDPRT name because Da Vinci will not print file names over 56 characters.
  • SolidWorks model of XYZPrinting filament cartridge spool included.

• Print both pieces. They are already oriented properly for printing, and no supports should be needed.
  • Remove the spool from inside a Da Vinci cartridge.
  • Place both pieces through the center of the spool, engaging the teeth from Side A into the holes on the spool. The pieces should press in snugly, and mate together in the middle.
  • Place a 4.5" long, 1/4" bolt, with one washer, through Side B (outer) and then in through Side A (inner).
  • Place another washer over the bolt, and secure with wingnut.
  • Chuck free end of bolt into an electric drill, and use it to wind filament onto the spool.

comments.text: Very nice improvements over the other DaVinci spool rewinder in fit and appearance! But I really like the hex bit driver in the other version. Need to blend the best ideas from both. I'd like to see a version of this with two interlocking pieces that doesn't need the long bolt, washer and wing nut.
comments.author: KDan

comments.text: Thanks for the feedback.  I too liked the idea of the hex bit, but decided to get rid of it in order to allow a real screw to hold it together (instead of the weak 3D printed screw), and to keep the unit simple (e.g. no gluing, no heating and pressing in the hex bit, etc.).  Even if I made one that used a hex bit to drive, I would insist on not having a printed screw.

title: Mendel X Carriage a la Prusa

description.text:
This is a modified Prusa Mendel X Carriage that will fit the standard Mendel X axis. It uses PLA bushings instead of the standard bearings.
The main difference is that it will clamp to the Mendel drive belt using the 2 clamps provided in the design.
A secondary difference is that it will hold the double-Wade seen in the background of the photo (details coming soon).

Print.  Fit X belt clamps with M4 screws, washers and nuts. Glue the plastic bushings into place on carriage body. It's a good idea to glue the M4 nuts for holding the extruder into the cavities as they are hard to reach. Push onto X axis rails and leave while glue sets. Clamp X drive belt on. Clamp on extruder ditto.
Once on the rails, it is hard to remove forcibly without breaking the bushings.

comments.text: looking for a vertical belt clamp that would work for my i2 rework - did you ever make a different version?  how did the pla work on the rods?

comments.text: New version coming up that will take a Wade with the gear hanging over the belt anchors, and has 4 belt clamps so you can use M4x40 bolts without cutting them.
